squidpony

Class GwtCompatibility

  • java.lang.Object
    • squidpony.GwtCompatibility

  • public class GwtCompatibility
extends Object
    Static methods useful to be GWT-compatible. You can think of the purpose of this class as "GWT, and Compatibility". There's a replacement for a Math method that isn't available on GWT, a quick way to get the first element in an Iterable, and also a method to easily clone a Coord array.
    Author:
    smelC, Tommy Ettinger

    • Method Detail

      • cloneCoords

        public static Coord[] cloneCoords(Coord[] input)
        Gets an exact copy of an array of Coord. References are shared, which should be the case for all usage of Coord since they are immutable and thus don't need multiple variants on a Coord from the pool.
        Parameters:
        input - an array of Coord to copy
        Returns:
        A clone of input.

      • IEEEremainder

        public static double IEEEremainder(double op,
                                   double d)
        A replacement for Math.IEEEremainder, just because Math.IEEEremainder isn't GWT-compatible. Gets the remainder of op / d, which can be negative if any parameter is negative.
        Parameters:
        op - the operand/dividend
        d - the divisor
        Returns:
        The remainder of op / d, as a double; can be negative

      • range

        @Deprecated
public static int[] range(int end)
        Deprecated. Use ArrayTools.range(int) instead.
        Stupidly simple convenience method that produces a range from 0 to end, not including end, as an int array. Delegates to ArrayTools, and using ArrayTools directly is preferred.
        Parameters:
        end - the exclusive upper bound on the range
        Returns:
        the range of ints as an int array

      • range

        @Deprecated
public static int[] range(int start,
                                       int end)
        Deprecated. Use ArrayTools.range(int, int) instead.
        Stupidly simple convenience method that produces a range from start to end, not including end, as an int array. Delegates to ArrayTools, and using ArrayTools directly is preferred.
        Parameters:
        start - the inclusive lower bound on the range
        end - the exclusive upper bound on the range
        Returns:
        the range of ints as an int array

      • charSpan

        @Deprecated
public static char[] charSpan(char start,
                                           char end)
        Deprecated. Use ArrayTools.charSpan(char, char) instead.
        Stupidly simple convenience method that produces a char range from start to end, including end, as a char array. Delegates to ArrayTools, and using ArrayTools directly is preferred.
        Parameters:
        start - the inclusive lower bound on the range, such as 'a'
        end - the inclusive upper bound on the range, such as 'z'
        Returns:
        the range of chars as a char array

      • letterSpan

        @Deprecated
public static char[] letterSpan(int charCount)
        Deprecated. Use ArrayTools.letterSpan(int) instead.
        Stupidly simple convenience method that produces a char array containing only letters that can be reasonably displayed (with SquidLib's default text display assets, at least). The letters are copied from a single source of 256 chars; if you need more chars or you don't need pure letters, you can use charSpan(char, char). Delegates to ArrayTools, and using ArrayTools directly is preferred.
        Parameters:
        charCount - the number of letters to return in an array; the maximum this will produce is 256
        Returns:
        the range of letters as a char array

      • first

        public static <T> T first(Iterable<T> collection)
        Gets the first item in an Iterable of T, or null if it is empty. Meant for collections like LinkedHashSet, which can promise a stable first element but don't provide a way to access it. Not exactly a GWT compatibility method, but more of a Java standard library stand-in. Even though LinkedHashSet does not support this out-of-the-box, OrderedSet already provides a first() method.
        Type Parameters:
        T - any object type
        Parameters:
        collection - an Iterable of T; if collection is null or empty this returns null
        Returns:
        the first element in collection, or null if it is empty or null itself

      • copy2D

        @Deprecated
public static char[][] copy2D(char[][] source)
        Deprecated. Use ArrayTools.copy(char[][]) instead.
        Gets a copy of the 2D char array, source, that has the same data but shares no references with source. Delegates to ArrayTools, and using ArrayTools directly is preferred.
        Parameters:
        source - a 2D char array
        Returns:
        a copy of source, or null if source is null

      • insert2D

        @Deprecated
public static char[][] insert2D(char[][] source,
                                             char[][] target,
                                             int x,
                                             int y)
        Deprecated. Use ArrayTools.insert(char[][], char[][], int, int) instead.
        Inserts as much of source into target at the given x,y position as target can hold or source can supply. Modifies target in-place and also returns target for chaining. Used primarily to place a smaller array into a different position in a larger array, often freshly allocated. Delegates to ArrayTools, and using ArrayTools directly is preferred.
        Parameters:
        source - a 2D char array that will be copied and inserted into target
        target - a 2D char array that will be modified by receiving as much of source as it can hold
        x - the x position in target to receive the items from the first cell in source
        y - the y position in target to receive the items from the first cell in source
        Returns:
        a modified copy of target with source inserted into it at the given position

      • insert2D

        @Deprecated
public static int[][] insert2D(int[][] source,
                                            int[][] target,
                                            int x,
                                            int y)
        Deprecated. Use ArrayTools.insert(int[][], int[][], int, int) instead.
        Inserts as much of source into target at the given x,y position as target can hold or source can supply. Modifies target in-place and also returns target for chaining. Used primarily to place a smaller array into a different position in a larger array, often freshly allocated. Delegates to ArrayTools, and using ArrayTools directly is preferred.
        Parameters:
        source - a 2D int array that will be copied and inserted into target
        target - a 2D int array that will be modified by receiving as much of source as it can hold
        x - the x position in target to receive the items from the first cell in source
        y - the y position in target to receive the items from the first cell in source
        Returns:
        a modified copy of target with source inserted into it at the given position

      • fill2D

        @Deprecated
public static char[][] fill2D(char contents,
                                           int width,
                                           int height)
        Deprecated. use ArrayTools.fill(char, int, int) instead.
        Creates a 2D array of the given width and height, filled with entirely with the value contents. Delegates to ArrayTools, and using ArrayTools directly is preferred.
        Parameters:
        contents - the value to fill the array with
        width - the desired width
        height - the desired height
        Returns:
        a freshly allocated 2D array of the requested dimensions, filled entirely with contents

      • reorder

        @Deprecated
public static <T> ArrayList<T> reorder(ArrayList<T> list,
                                                    int... ordering)
        Deprecated. Use ArrayTools.reorder(ArrayList, int...) instead.
        Rearranges an ArrayList to use the given ordering, returning a copy; random orderings can be produced with RNG.randomOrdering(int) or RNG.randomOrdering(int, int[]). These orderings will never repeat an earlier element, and the returned ArrayList may be shorter than the original if ordering isn't as long as list. Using a random ordering is like shuffling, but allows you to repeat the shuffle exactly on other collections of the same size. A reordering can also be inverted with invertOrdering(int[]) or invertOrdering(int[], int[]), getting the change that will undo another ordering. Delegates to ArrayTools, and using ArrayTools directly is preferred.
        Type Parameters:
        T - any generic type
        Parameters:
        list - an ArrayList that you want a reordered version of; will not be modified.
        ordering - an ordering, typically produced by one of RNG's randomOrdering methods.
        Returns:
        a modified copy of list with its ordering changed to match ordering.

      • invertOrdering

        @Deprecated
public static int[] invertOrdering(int[] ordering)
        Deprecated. Use ArrayTools.invertOrdering(int[]) instead.
        Given an ordering such as one produced by RNG.randomOrdering(int, int[]), this finds its inverse, able to reverse the reordering and vice versa. Delegates to ArrayTools, and using ArrayTools directly is preferred.
        Parameters:
        ordering - the ordering to find the inverse for
        Returns:
        the inverse of ordering

      • invertOrdering

        @Deprecated
public static int[] invertOrdering(int[] ordering,
                                                int[] dest)
        Deprecated. Use ArrayTools.invertOrdering(int[], int[]) instead.
        Given an ordering such as one produced by RNG.randomOrdering(int, int[]), this finds its inverse, able to reverse the reordering and vice versa. This overload doesn't allocate a new int array, and instead relies on having an int array of the same size as ordering passed to it as an additional argument. Delegates to ArrayTools, and using ArrayTools directly is preferred.
        Parameters:
        ordering - the ordering to find the inverse for
        dest - the int array to put the inverse reordering into; should have the same length as ordering
        Returns:
        the inverse of ordering; will have the same value as dest
